results.title: What should I do: the fight
results.creator_credit: Les Clark, Ken Peterson and Walt Disney Animation Studios
results.brief_description: An animated film which offers a number of solutions to children on how to deal with others who want to start fights. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: What should happen?: investigating community decision making
results.creator_credit: James Mann and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: An account of how a Year 9/10 class investigate a local issue, and in doing so, learn about the political process. Demonstrates the inquiry process in practice, emphasising collaborative learning, well planned field work and classroom reflection. Students are able to observe the tactics used by protagonists to influence the decision-making process.

results.title: What sex is your job?
results.brief_description: Looks at the characteristics of women’s work in three different areas where it is seen to be tedious, badly paid or involves physical stress. In each section there is a point being made about the underlying discrimination against women.

results.title: What rights has a child
results.creator_credit: Elspeth MacDougall, Ben Park and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Uses children’s art from all over the world with commentary by the children as they talk about each of the clauses of the “Universal Declaration of the Rights of the Child” an what they means to them. Juxtaposes the children’s artwork and their views with often quite graphic photography of war , famine, poverty, and violence. Includes artwork from Terezin Concentration Camp and disturbing camp stills. Not for children’s viewing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Elspeth MacDougall, Ben Park and United Nations Television

results.title: What psychologists do (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Introduction to Psychology”.
John Annett looks at work being done by six psychologists in the following areas: acquisition of reading skills, computer assisted learning, vocational guidance, design of industrial machine tools, diagnosis of brain damage, work with chronic, mute schizophrenics. He points out the close relationship between psychological research and its application to real life problems.

group_siblings.creator_credit: Carol Haslam, BBC-TV and Open University

results.title: What price water
results.creator_credit: David Cons, G. Buckland-Smith and GBS Productions
results.brief_description: Britain is the leading exporter of desalination plants. All over the world plants are providing fresh water for consumption by industry, agriculture and in the home. Details the extensive research and development programmes on a number of techniques: multi-stage flash distillation, electrodialysis, reverse osmosis and freezing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Cons, G. Buckland-Smith and GBS Productions

results.title: What Price Valour
results.brief_description: A program about an Australian, Edgar Tauner, who was awarded the Victoria Cross. The program examines the attributes that are required for a person to be awarded the honour and distinction of the VC

results.title: What price glory?
results.creator_credit: John Ford, Sol Siegel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: John Ford’s colourful screen adaptation of Maxwell Anderson and Laurence Stalling’s raucous army comedy. James Cagney plays Captain Flagg, a hard-boiled leader of a company of US Marines stationed in France during the World War I. Dan Dailey plays the quirky newly arrived Sergeant Quirk and it is not long before the two of them are at loggerheads. When the beautiful Charmaine (Corrine Calvert) becomes the object of their attentions, the war is really on. Watch for a young Robert Wagner in one of his early screen roles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Ford, Sol Siegel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation

group_siblings.title: Victor McLaglen, Dolores del Rio and Edmund Lowe on the set of What Price Glory

results.title: What people are calling PMS
results.creator_credit: Haida Paul, Barbara Janes, Jennifer Torrance and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film explores the confusion and negativity surrounding the subject of Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS). Based on the premise that premenstrual changes are normal rather than an illness, the film provides health information and presents some of the positive aspects of the premenstrual phase. Featured are women who speak candidly about their experiences of PMS.
